title-group.article-title: Quantifying the shape of cells, from Minkowski tensors to p-atic orders

abstract.p: P-atic liquid crystal theories offer new perspectives on how cells self-organize and respond to mechanical cues. Understanding and quantifying the underlying orientational orders is, therefore, essential for unraveling the physical mechanisms that govern tissue dynamics. Due to the deformability of cells this requires quantifying their shape. We introduce rigorous mathematical tools and a reliable framework for such shape analysis. Applying this to segmented cells in MDCK monolayers and computational approaches for active vertex models and multiphase field models allows to demonstrate independence of shape measures and the presence of various p-atic orders at the same time. This challenges previous findings and opens new pathways for understanding the role of orientational symmetries and p-atic liquid crystal theories in tissue mechanics and development.

custom-meta.meta-value: Only rigorous mathematical tools to quantify the shape of cells can guarantee reliable results in coarse-grained descriptions of tissue dynamics.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The importance of orientational order in biological systems is becoming increasingly clear, as it plays a critical role in processes such as tissue morphogenesis, collective cell motion, and cellular extrusion. Orientational order results from the shapes of cells and their alignments with neighboring cells. Disruptions in this order, known as topological defects, are often linked to key biological events. For instance, defects—points or lines where the order breaks down—can drive cell extrusion (Saw et al., 2017; Monfared et al., 2023) or trigger morphological changes in tissues (Maroudas-Sacks et al., 2021; Ravichandran et al., 2025). Orientational order is linked to liquid crystal theories (de Gennes, 1993) and should here be interpreted in a broad sense. Recent evidence extends beyond nematic order, characterized by symmetry under 180∘=2π/2\begin{document}$180^{\circ}=2\pi/2$\end{document} rotation, to higher-order symmetries such as tetratic order (90∘=2π/4\begin{document}$90^{\circ}=2\pi/4$\end{document}), hexatic order (60∘=2π/6\begin{document}$60^{\circ}=2\pi/6$\end{document}), and even general p-atic orders (2π/p\begin{document}$2\pi/p$\end{document}, p\begin{document}$p$\end{document} being an integer). In biological contexts, nematic order (p=2\begin{document}$p=2$\end{document}) has been widely studied in epithelial tissues (Duclos et al., 2017; Saw et al., 2017; Kawaguchi et al., 2017), linking defects to cellular behaviors and tissue organization. More complex orders, such as tetratic order (p=4\begin{document}$p=4$\end{document}) (Cislo et al., 2023) and hexatic oder (p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document}) (Li and Ciamarra, 2018; Durand and Heu, 2019; Pasupalak et al., 2020; Armengol-Collado et al., 2023; Eckert et al., 2023), have also been observed in experimental systems, offering new perspectives on how cells self-organize and respond to mechanical cues. Understanding and quantifying orientational order and the corresponding liquid crystal theory are, therefore, essential for unraveling the physical mechanisms that govern biological dynamics.

In physics, p-atic liquid crystals illustrate how particle shape and symmetry influence phase behavior, with seminal works dating back to Onsager’s theories (Onsager, 1949). Most prominently, hexatic order (p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document}) has been postulated and found by experiments and simulations as an intermediate state between crystalline solid and isotropic liquid in Halperin and Nelson, 1978; Nelson and Halperin, 1979; Murray and van Winkle, 1987; Bladon and Frenkel, 1995; Zahn et al., 1999; Gasser et al., 2010; Bernard and Krauth, 2011. Other examples are colloidal systems for triadic platelets (Bowick et al., 2017) or cubes (Wojciechowski and Frenkel, 2004), which lead to p-atic order with p=3\begin{document}$p=3$\end{document} and p=4\begin{document}$p=4$\end{document}, respectively. Even pentatic (p=5\begin{document}$p=5$\end{document}) and heptatic (p=7\begin{document}$p=7$\end{document}) liquid crystals have been engineered (Wang and Mason, 2018; Yu and Mason, 2024). The corresponding liquid crystal theories for p-atic order have only recently been defined (Giomi et al., 2022b; Krommydas et al., 2023) and can also be used in biological contexts. However, while in colloidal systems particle shapes remain fixed, in biological tissues, cells are dynamic: their shapes are irregular, variable, and influenced by internal and external forces. These unique properties make quantifying p-atic order in tissues significantly more challenging, as quantification of the cell shapes is required. We will demonstrate that existing methods, such as bond-orientational order (Nelson and Halperin, 1979) or polygonal shape analysis (Armengol-Collado et al., 2023), might fail to capture the nuances of irregular cell shapes, which has severe consequences on the definition of p-atic order.

To address this, we adapt Minkowski tensors (Mecke, 2000; Schröder-Turk et al., 2013)—rigorous mathematical tools for shape analysis—to quantify p-atic orders in cell monolayers. Minkowski tensors provide robust and sensitive measures of shape anisotropy and orientation, accommodating both smooth and polygonal shapes while remaining resilient to small perturbations. By applying these tools, we re-examine previous conclusions about p-atic orders in epithelial tissues and demonstrate that certain widely accepted results require reconsideration.

Our study leverages a combination of experimental and computational approaches. Experimentally, we analyze confluent monolayers of MDCK (Madin-Darby Canine Kidney) cells. Figure 1 provide a snapshot of a considered monolayer of 235 wild-type MDCK cells, together with their shape classification by Minkowski tensors. The corresponding statistical data and probability distributions of these quantities are shown in Figure 2. These data indicate the presence of all p-atic orders at once with similar probability distributions, mean values, and standard deviations. In addition to these experiments, we also analyze data of MDCK cells reported in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023. Computationally, we employ two complementary models for cell monolayers: the active vertex model and the multiphase field model. These approaches allow us to systematically vary parameters such as cell activity and mechanical properties, providing a comprehensive view of how p-atic orders emerges in different contexts.

(b-f) Minkowski tensor, visualized using ϑp\begin{document}$\vartheta_{p}$\end{document} and qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document}, Equation 7 (see Methods) for p=2,3,4,5,6\begin{document}$p=2,3,4,5,6$\end{document}, respectively. The brightness and the rotation of the p-atic director indicates the magnitude and the orientation, respectively. The visualization uses rotationally symmetric direction fields known as p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}-RoSy fields in computer graphics (Vaxman et al., 2016). (b- f) Probability distribution function (PDF) of qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document} for p=2,3,4,5,6\begin{document}$p=2,3,4,5,6$\end{document}, respectively. Kde-plots are used to show the probability distribution.

sec.p: By combining these robust mathematical tools, experimental insights, and computational models, we establish a reliable framework for quantifying p-atic orders in biological tissues. This framework not only challenges previous findings, e.g. a proposed hexatic-nematic crossover on larger length scales (Armengol-Collado et al., 2023), but also opens new pathways for understanding the role of orientational symmetries in tissue mechanics and development, which require to consider multiple orientational symmetries.

sec.title: Minkowski tensors for shape classification
sec.p: Essential properties of the geometry of a two-dimensional object are summarized by scalar-valued size measures, so called Minkowski functionals. They are defined by(1)W0(C)=∫CdC,W1(C)=∫∂Cd∂C, andW2(C)=∫∂CHd∂C,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle W_0({\cal{C}}) = \int_{{\cal{C}}}\,{\rm d}{\cal{C}},\quad W_1({\cal{C}}) = \int_{\partial {\cal{C}}}\,{\rm d}\partial {\cal{C}},\ \text{and}\quad W_2({\cal{C}}) = \int_{\partial {\cal{C}}} {\cal{H}}\,{\rm d}\partial {\cal{C}},$$\end{document}

where C\begin{document}${\cal{C}}$\end{document} is the smooth two-dimensional object, with contour ∂C\begin{document}$\partial{\cal{C}}$\end{document} and H\begin{document}${\cal{H}}$\end{document} denotes the curvature of the contour ∂C\begin{document}$\partial{\cal{C}}$\end{document} (see Figure 3 for a schematic description), as reviewed in Mecke, 2000. They describe the area, the perimeter, and a curvature-weighted integral of the contour, respectively. Minkowski functionals are also known as intrinsic volumes. For convex objects, they have been shown to be continuous and invariant to translations and rotations. Due to these properties and Hadwiger’s characterization theorem (Hadwiger, 1975), they are natural size descriptors that provide essential and complete information about invariant geometric features. However, these properties also set limits to their use as shape descriptors. Due to rotation invariance, they are unable to capture the orientation of the shape. To describe more complex shape information, the scalar-valued Minkowski functionals are extended to a set of tensor-valued descriptors, known as Minkowski tensors. These objects have been investigated both in mathematical (Alesker, 1999; Hug et al., 2008a; Hug et al., 2008b; McMullen, 1997) and in physical literature (Schröder-Turk et al., 2010b; Kapfer, 2012). Using tensor products of the position vectors r\begin{document}$\mathbf{r}$\end{document} and the normal vectors n\begin{document}$\mathbf{n}$\end{document} of the contour ∂C\begin{document}$\partial{\cal{C}}$\end{document}, defined as ra⊙nb=r⊙…⊙r⊙n⊙…⊙n\begin{document}$\mathbf{r}^{a}\odot\mathbf{n}^{b}=\mathbf{r}\odot\ldots\odot\mathbf{r}\odot \mathbf{n}\odot\ldots\odot\mathbf{n}$\end{document}, the first considered a\begin{document}$a$\end{document} times and the last b\begin{document}$b$\end{document} times with ⊙\begin{document}$\odot$\end{document} denoting the symmetrized tensor product, the Minkowski tensors are defined as(2)W0a,0(C)=∫CradC,W1a,b(C)=∫∂Cra⊙nbd∂C, andW2a,b(C)=∫∂Cra⊙nbHd∂C.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathbf{W}_0^{a,0}({\cal{C}}) = \int_{{\cal{C}}} \mathbf{r}^a\,{\rm d}{\cal{C}},\quad \mathbf{W}_1^{a,b}({\cal{C}}) = \int_{\partial {\cal{C}}} \mathbf{r}^a \odot \mathbf{n}^b\,{\rm d}\partial {\cal{C}},\ \text{and}\quad \mathbf{W}_2^{a,b}({\cal{C}}) = \int_{\partial {\cal{C}}} \mathbf{r}^a \odot \mathbf{n}^b{\cal{H}}\,{\rm d}\partial {\cal{C}}.$$\end{document}

caption.title: Schematic description of a two-dimensional object C\begin{document}$\mathcal{C}$\end{document} with contour ∂C\begin{document}$\partial{\cal{C}}$\end{document}.
caption.p: We denote the center of mass with xc\begin{document}$\mathbf{x}_{c}$\end{document} and vectors from xc\begin{document}$\mathbf{x}_{c}$\end{document} to points x\begin{document}$\mathbf{x}$\end{document} on ∂C\begin{document}$\partial{\cal{C}}$\end{document} with r\begin{document}$\mathbf{r}$\end{document}. The outward-pointing normals are denoted by n\begin{document}$\mathbf{n}$\end{document}, the corresponding angle with the x\begin{document}$x$\end{document}-axis by θn\begin{document}$\theta_{\mathbf{n}}$\end{document}.

sec.p: For Wj0,0(C)=Wj(C)\begin{document}$\mathbf{W}_{j}^{0,0}({\cal{C})}=W_{j}({\cal{C})}$\end{document} for j=0,1,2\begin{document}$j=0,1,2$\end{document}, so the Minkowski tensors are extensions of the Minkowski functionals. In analogy to Minkowski functionals, also Minkowski tensors have been shown to be continuous for convex objects. Also, analogies to Hadwiger’s characterization theorem exist (Alesker, 1999). However, for our purpose, the essential property is the continuity. It makes Minkowski functionals and Minkowski tensors a robust measure as small shape changes lead to small changes in the shape descriptor. Due to this property, Minkowski tensors have been successfully used as shape descriptors in different fields, e.g., in materials science as a robust measure of anisotropy in porous (Schröder‐Turk et al., 2010a) and granular material (Schröder-Turk et al., 2013), in astrophysics to describe morphology of galaxies (Beisbart, 2002), and in biology to distinguish shapes of different types of neuronal cell networks (Beisbart et al., 2006) and to determine the direction of elongation in multiphase field models for epithelial tissue (Mueller et al., 2019; Wenzel and Voigt, 2021; Happel and Voigt, 2024). However, the mentioned examples exclusively use lower-rank Minkowski tensors a+b≤2\begin{document}$a+b\leq 2$\end{document}. Higher rank tensors have not been considered in such applications, but the theory also guarantees robust description of p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}-atic orientation for p=3,4,5,6,…\begin{document}$p=3,4,5,6,\ldots$\end{document}. These results hold for smooth contours but can also be extended to polyconvex shapes. Furthermore, known counterexamples for non-convex shapes have very little to no relevance in applications (Kapfer et al., 2012).

Even if all Minkowski tensors carry important geometric information, one type is particularly interesting and will be considered in the following:(3)W10,p(C)=∫∂Cn⊙n⊙…⊙n⏟p−timesd∂C.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \boldsymbol{W}_1^{0,p}({\cal{C}})=\int_{\partial {\cal{C}}} \underbrace{\mathbf{n} \odot \mathbf{n} \odot \ldots \odot \mathbf{n}}_{\text p-times}\,{\rm d} \partial {\cal{C}}.$$\end{document}

In this case, the symmetrized tensor product agrees with the classical tensor product. If applied to polygonal shapes the Minkowski tensors W10,p(C)\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{W}_{1}^{0,p}({\cal{C}})$\end{document} are related to the Minkowski problem for convex polytops (i.e. generalizations of three-dimensional polyhedra to an arbitrary number of dimensions), which states that convex polytops are uniquely described by the outer normals of the edges and the length of the corresponding edge (Minkowski, 1897). Several generalizations of this result exist (Klain, 2004; Schneider, 2013), which makes the normal vectors a preferable quantity to describe shapes. However, Minkowski tensors contain redundant information, which asks for an irreducible representation. This can be achieved by decomposing the tensor with respect to the rotation group SO(2)\begin{document}$SO(2)$\end{document} (Kapfer, 2012; Mickel et al., 2013; Klatt et al., 2022). Following this approach, one can write(4)W10,p(C)=∫S1upΨC(u)duwithΨC(u)=∫∂Cδ(n(x)−u)d∂C,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \boldsymbol{W}_1^{0,p}({\cal{C}}) = \int_{S^1} \mathbf{u}^p \Psi_{\cal{C}}(\mathbf{u})\,{\rm d}\mathbf{u} \quad \mbox{with} \quad \Psi_{\cal{C}} (\mathbf{u}) = \int_{\partial {\cal{C}}} \delta(\mathbf{n}(\mathbf{x}) - \mathbf{u})\,{\rm d}\partial {\cal{C}},$$\end{document}

with ΨC(u)\begin{document}$\Psi_{\cal{C}}(\mathbf{u})$\end{document} being proportional to the probability density of the normal vectors. Identifying u∈S1\begin{document}$\mathbf{u}\in S^{1}$\end{document} by the angle θ\begin{document}$\theta$\end{document} between u\begin{document}$\mathbf{u}$\end{document} and the x-axis allows to write(5)ΨC(θ)=∑p=−∞∞ψp(C)e−ipθwithψp(C)=12π∫02πΨC(θ)eipθdθ.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Psi_{\cal{C}}(\theta) = \sum_{p = - \infty}^\infty \psi_p({\cal{C}}) e^{-i p \theta} \quad \mbox{with} \quad \psi_p({\cal{C}}) = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2 \pi} \Psi_{\cal{C}}(\theta) e^{i p \theta}\,{\rm d}\theta .$$\end{document}

The Fourier coefficients ψp(C)\begin{document}$\psi_{p}({\cal{C}})$\end{document} are the irreducible representations of W10,p(C)\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{W}_{1}^{0,p}({\cal{C}})$\end{document} and can be written as(6)ψp(C)=12π∫∂Ceipθnd∂C,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \psi_p({\cal{C}})=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{\partial\cal{C}} e^{ip\theta_{\boldsymbol{n}}}\,{\rm d} \partial\mathcal{C},$$\end{document}

where θn\begin{document}$\theta_{\boldsymbol{n}}$\end{document} is the orientation of the outward pointing normal n\begin{document}$\mathbf{n}$\end{document}. The phase of the complex number ψp(C)\begin{document}$\psi_{p}({\cal{C}})$\end{document} contains information about the preferred orientation and the absolute value |ψp(C)|\begin{document}$|\psi_{p}({\cal{C}})|$\end{document} is a scalar index. We thus define(7)ϑp(C)=1parctan⁡2(ℑψp(C),ℜψp(C))+πpandqp(C)=|ψp(C)|ψ0(C),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \vartheta_p({\cal{C}})=\frac{1}{p} \arctan2 \left(\Im \psi_p({\cal{C}}),\Re \psi_p({\cal{C}}) \right) + \frac{\pi}{p}\quad \mbox{and} \quad q_p({\cal{C}}) = \frac{|\psi_p({\cal{C}})|}{\psi_0({\cal{C}})},$$\end{document}

with ℑψp\begin{document}$\Im\psi_{p}$\end{document} and ℜψp\begin{document}$\Re\psi_{p}$\end{document} the imaginary and real part of ψp\begin{document}$\psi_{p}$\end{document}, respectively, and ψ0(C)=W1(C)2π\begin{document}$\psi_{0}({\cal{C}})=\frac{W_{1}({\cal{C}})}{2\pi}$\end{document}. We have qp(C)∈[0,1]\begin{document}${q_{p}({\cal{C}})\in[0,1]}$\end{document} quantifying the strength of p-atic order. Figure 4 illustrates the concept for polygonal and smooth shapes and Figure 5 illustrates the calculation of qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document} and ϑp\begin{document}$\vartheta_{p}$\end{document} at the example of an equilateral triangle. Note that the constant factor of 1/(2π)\begin{document}$1/(2\pi)$\end{document} in Equation 6 does not influence the result of Equation 7 and is, therefore, disregarded in Figure 5. Alternative derivations of Equation 7 consider higher order trace-less tensors (Virga, 2015; Giomi et al., 2022b; Armengol-Collado et al., 2023) generated by the normal n\begin{document}$\mathbf{n}$\end{document}. In this case ϑp(C)\begin{document}$\vartheta_{p}({\cal{C}})$\end{document} (orange triatic director in Figure 5 right) corresponds to the eigenvector to the negative eigenvalue and ϑp(C)−π/p\begin{document}$\vartheta_{p}({\cal{C}})-\pi/p$\end{document} (gray triatic director in Figure 5 right) to the eigenvector to the positive eigenvalue. For p=2\begin{document}$p=2$\end{document}, this tensor-based approach corresponds to the structure tensor (Mueller et al., 2019).

caption.title: Regular and irregular shapes, adapted from Armengol-Collado et al., 2023 and Schaller et al., 2024, by Equation 7.
caption.p: For regular shapes, the corresponding magnitude of qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document} is always 1.0\begin{document}$1.0$\end{document} and the detected angle is the minimal angle of the p-atic orientation with respect to the x\begin{document}$x$\end{document}-axis. Note that no shape with q2=1.0\begin{document}$q_{2}=1.0$\end{document} is shown, as this would be a line. The visualization is according to Figure 1.

caption.title: Illustrative description of the definition of q3\begin{document}$q_{3}$\end{document} for an equilateral triangle.
caption.p: Considering rotational symmetries under a rotation 120∘=2π/3\begin{document}$120^{\circ}=2\pi/3$\end{document} means that vectors with an angle of 120∘\begin{document}$120^{\circ}$\end{document} or 240∘\begin{document}$240^{\circ}$\end{document} are treated as equal. Applied to the normals n\begin{document}$\mathbf{n}$\end{document} (left), this means that under this rotational symmetry, the normals on the three different edges are equal. Mathematically, this is expressed through e3iθn\begin{document}$e^{3i\theta_{\mathbf{n}}}$\end{document} resulting in the triatic director shown instead of the normals n\begin{document}$\mathbf{n}$\end{document} (middle). One leg of the triatic director always points in the direction as the normal. While only shown for three points on each edge, we obtain an orientation with the respective symmetry on every point of the contour ∂C\begin{document}$\partial{\cal{C}}$\end{document}. Considering the line integral along the contour provides the dominating triadic director, shown in the center of mass (right). To get a value between 0.0\begin{document}$0.0$\end{document} and 1.0\begin{document}$1.0$\end{document} for q3\begin{document}$q_{3}$\end{document}, we normalize this integral with the length of the contour, which corresponds to q0\begin{document}$q_{0}$\end{document}. As all triatic directors point in the same direction, we obtain q3=1.0\begin{document}$q_{3}=1.0$\end{document} in this specific example. To be consistent with other approaches, we rotate the resulting triadic director by 60∘=π/3\begin{document}$60^{\circ}=\pi/3$\end{document} leading to the orange triadic director, which is the quantity used for visualization.

sec.title: Alternative shape measures
sec.p: As pointed out in the introduction, p-atic orders have already been identified in biological tissue and model systems. However, the way to quantify rotational symmetry in these works differs from the Minkowski tensors. In Armengol-Collado et al., 2023, the cell contour is approximated by a polygon with V\begin{document}$V$\end{document} vertices having coordinates xi\begin{document}$\mathbf{x}_{i}$\end{document}. The considered polygonal shape analysis is based on the shape function(8)γp(C)=∑i=1V|ri|peipθi∑i=1V|ri|p,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \gamma_p(C) = \frac{\sum_{i = 1}^V |\mathbf{r}_i|^p e^{\mathrm{i} p \theta_i}}{\sum_{i = 1}^V |\mathbf{r}_i|^p}, $$\end{document}

with ri=xi−xc\begin{document}$\mathbf{r}_{i}=\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{c}$\end{document} being the vector from the centroid xc\begin{document}$\mathbf{x}_{c}$\end{document} and θi\begin{document}$\theta_{i}$\end{document} being the orientation of the i\begin{document}$i$\end{document}-th vertex of the polygon with respect to its center of mass. As the centroid is computed by xc=1V∑i=1Vxi\begin{document}$\mathbf{x}_{c}=\frac{1}{V}\sum_{i=1}^{V}\mathbf{x}_{i}$\end{document} Armengol-Collado et al., 2023 the only input data are the coordinates of the vertices of the V\begin{document}$V$\end{document}-sided polygon. Equation 8 captures the degree of regularity of the polygon by its amplitude 0≤|γp|≤1\begin{document}$0\leq|\gamma_{p}|\leq 1$\end{document} and its orientation ϑpγ\begin{document}$\vartheta^{\gamma}_{p}$\end{document} which follows as(9)ϑpγ(C)=1parctan⁡ℑγp(C)ℜγp(C),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \vartheta^\gamma_p(C) = \frac{1}{p} \arctan \frac{\Im \gamma_p(C)}{\Re \gamma_p(C)},$$\end{document}

with ℑγp\begin{document}$\Im\gamma_{p}$\end{document} and ℜγp\begin{document}$\Re\gamma_{p}$\end{document} the imaginary and real part of γp\begin{document}$\gamma_{p}$\end{document}, respectively. Instead of the normals n\begin{document}$\mathbf{n}$\end{document}, the descriptor is based on the position vector r\begin{document}$\mathbf{r}$\end{document}. One might be tempted to think that Equation 9 is related to the irreducible representation of W1p,0\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{W}_{1}^{p,0}$\end{document}. This is, however, not the case, as the weighting in Equation 8 is done with respect to the magnitude of r\begin{document}$\mathbf{r}$\end{document}, while in W1p,0\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{W}_{1}^{p,0}$\end{document} the weighting is done with respect to the contour integral. Furthermore, in contrast to the Minkowski tensors, Equation 8 takes into account only the vectors at the vertices and not the vectors along the full cell contour. While this seems to be a technical detail, it has severe consequences. The theoretical basis, which guarantees continuity, no longer holds. This leads to unstable behaviour, as illustrated in Figure 6. While the shape of the polygons is almost identical, there is a jump in γ3\begin{document}$\gamma_{3}$\end{document} and γ4\begin{document}$\gamma_{4}$\end{document} as we go from four to three vertices. The weighting according to the magnitude cannot cure this, as the magnitude of the shrinking vector is far from zero shortly before this vertex vanishes. In the context of cellular systems, such deformations are a regular occurrence rather than an artificially constructed test case. We will demonstrate the impact while discussing the results and recommend only using robust descriptors such as the Minkowski tensors or their irreducible representations.

caption.title: Defining p-atic order for deformable objects requires robust shape descriptors.
caption.p: Shown is the strength of p-atic order for a polygon converging to an equilateral triangle. (a) using qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document} and (b) using γp\begin{document}$\gamma_{p}$\end{document}. The considered vectors used in the computations, normals n\begin{document}$\mathbf{n}$\end{document} of the contour for the Minkowski tensors and ri\begin{document}$\mathbf{r}_{i}$\end{document} for γp\begin{document}$\gamma_{p}$\end{document}, are shown. Note that the removal of the forth vertex highly influences the value of γp\begin{document}$\gamma_{p}$\end{document}. How xc\begin{document}$\mathbf{x}_{c}$\end{document} is calculated - as the mean of the vertex coordinates or as the center of mass of the polygon - can also slightly alter the results. We used the described approach following Armengol-Collado et al., 2023.

sec.p: We further note that bond order parameters Ψpbond\begin{document}$\Psi^{bond}_{p}$\end{document}, which consider the connection between cells, have also been used as shape descriptors (Li and Ciamarra, 2018; Durand and Heu, 2019; Pasupalak et al., 2020). Introduced in Nelson and Halperin, 1979, these parameters are(10)Ψpbond=1B∑b=1Beipθb,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle {\Psi^{bond}_p=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{b=1}^B e^{ip\theta_b}}, $$\end{document}

with B\begin{document}$B$\end{document} denoting the number of bonds and θb\begin{document}$\theta_{b}$\end{document} the orientation of the bond b\begin{document}$b$\end{document}. In the context of monolayer tissues, B\begin{document}$B$\end{document} is understood as the number of neighbors, and θb\begin{document}$\theta_{b}$\end{document} as the orientation of the connection of the center of mass of the current cell with the center of mass of the neighbor b\begin{document}$b$\end{document} (Loewe et al., 2020; Monfared et al., 2023). So, cells with the same contour but different neighbor relations lead to different bond order parameters. This characteristic should already disqualify these measures as shape descriptors. However, as discussed in detail in Mickel et al., 2013, they are not robust even for the task they are designed for. We, therefore, do not discuss them further. The same argumentation holds for other measures which are based on connectivity, as, e.g., considered in Graner et al., 2008; Merkel et al., 2017.

sec.title: Coarse-grained quantities
sec.p: We define coarse-grained quantities, following closely the strategy used in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023. We, therefore, regard the coarse-grained strength of p-atic order Qp=Qp(x)\begin{document}$Q_{p}=Q_{p}(\mathbf{x})$\end{document}, which is the average of all shape functions ψpψ0\begin{document}$\frac{\psi_{p}}{\psi_{0}}$\end{document} (or equivalently qpeipϑp\begin{document}$q_{p}e^{ip\vartheta_{p}}$\end{document}) of cells whose center of mass xc\begin{document}$\mathbf{x}_{c}$\end{document} lies within a circle with radius R\begin{document}$R$\end{document} and center x\begin{document}$\mathbf{x}$\end{document}. In a formula, this is:(11)QP(x)=∑j=1Nqp(Cj)eipϑp(Cj)Θ(R−|x−xc(Cj)|)∑j=1NΘ(R−|x−xc(Cj)|)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle Q_P(\mathbf{x})=\frac{\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}q_p(\mathcal{C}_j)e^{ip\vartheta_p(\mathcal{C}_j)}\Theta(R-|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_c(\mathcal{C}_j)|)}{\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}\Theta(R-|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_c(\mathcal{C}_j)|)}$$\end{document}

where N\begin{document}$N$\end{document} is the number of cells. Ci\begin{document}$\mathcal{C}_{i}$\end{document} denotes the i-th cell and Θ\begin{document}$\Theta$\end{document} denotes the Heaviside step function with Θ(x)=1\begin{document}$\Theta(x)=1$\end{document} for x>0\begin{document}$x \gt 0$\end{document} and Θ(x)=0\begin{document}$\Theta(x)=0$\end{document} otherwise. As Armengol-Collado et al., 2023 the position x\begin{document}$\mathbf{x}$\end{document} is sampled over a square grid with a spacing close to the mean cell radius Rcell\begin{document}$R_{cell}$\end{document}. We calculate this as Rcell=ACπ\begin{document}$R_{cell}=\sqrt{\frac{A_{\mathcal{C}}}{\pi}}$\end{document} with AC\begin{document}$A_{\mathcal{C}}$\end{document} the cell area. Equation 11 provides the basis for validation of continuous p-atic liquid crystal theories on the tissue scale, e.g., (Giomi et al., 2022b; Giomi et al., 2022a). For comparison, we also consider the coarse-grained shape function Γp=Γp(x)\begin{document}$\Gamma_{p}=\Gamma_{p}(\mathbf{x})$\end{document}, which is the average of all shape functions γp\begin{document}$\gamma_{p}$\end{document}, which has been considered in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023 and reads(12)Γp(x)=∑j=1Nγp(Cj)Θ(R−|x−xc(Cj)|)∑j=1NΘ(R−|x−xc(Cj)|).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Gamma_p(\mathbf{x})=\frac{\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}\gamma_p(\mathcal{C}_j)\Theta(R-|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_c(\mathcal{C}_j)|)}{\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}\Theta(R-|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_c(\mathcal{C}_j)|)}.$$\end{document}

Following Armengol-Collado et al., 2023 xc\begin{document}$\mathbf{x}_{c}$\end{document} is calculated as xc=1V∑i=1Vxi\begin{document}$\mathbf{x}_{c}=\frac{1}{V}\sum_{i=1}^{V}\mathbf{x}_{i}$\end{document} for Γp\begin{document}$\Gamma_{p}$\end{document}.

While Qp\begin{document}$Q_{p}$\end{document} and Γp\begin{document}$\Gamma_{p}$\end{document} allow to analyze clustering on the tissue scale, their averages Qp¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{p}}$\end{document} and Γp¯\begin{document}$\overline{\Gamma_{p}}$\end{document} are tightly related to the statistical properties of the probability distributions of qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document} and |γp|\begin{document}$|\gamma_{p}|$\end{document}. We consider these properties only for comparison and follow the method used in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023: At first, we calculate for every time instance/frame the spatial means, Qpt\begin{document}$Q_{p}^{t}$\end{document} and Γpt\begin{document}$\Gamma_{p}^{t}$\end{document}, by averaging over all grid points. Then we calculate Qp¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{p}}$\end{document} and Γp¯\begin{document}$\overline{\Gamma_{p}}$\end{document} by averaging in time, so averaging over all Qpt\begin{document}$Q_{p}^{t}$\end{document} and Γpt\begin{document}$\Gamma_{p}^{t}$\end{document}. As in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023, the s.e.m. and the standard deviation refer to the averaging in time. Qp¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{p}}$\end{document} and Γp¯\begin{document}$\overline{\Gamma_{p}}$\end{document} will be used for the discussion of a proposed hexatic-nematic crossover at larger length scales (Armengol-Collado et al., 2023).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Quantifying orientational order in biological tissues can be realized by Minkowski tensors. The orientation ϑp\begin{document}$\vartheta_{p}$\end{document} and the strength of p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}-atic order qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document} in Equation 7 can be computed for each cell. Minkowski tensors provide reliable quantities describing how cell shapes align with specific rotational symmetries. As already indicated in Figure 2, situations might occur in which rotational symmetries cannot be associated with one specific p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}, but various symmetries seem to be present at the same time. One might be tempted to compare the probability distribution functions (PDFs) of qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document} or the mean values qp¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{p}}$\end{document} for different p\begin{document}$p$\end{document} in order to identify a dominating p-atic order. This is particularly important for interpreting nematic (p=2\begin{document}$p=2$\end{document}) and hexatic (p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document}) orders, which describe distinct symmetries but have been found to coexist in biological systems. However, a direct comparison of these quantities only makes sense if they are comparable to each other. As already mentioned in Figure 4, this is not the case, as, e.g., q2=1.0\begin{document}$q_{2}=1.0$\end{document} cannot be realized for a cell with a given area. Another question one might ask is if these values are independent of each other. To answer this question, we first address statistically if q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document}, evaluated for each cell, are independent. Second, we explore how qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document} depends on key parameters determining tissue mechanics. In a third step, we coarse-grain these quantities using the measures Q2\begin{document}${Q}_{2}$\end{document} and Q6\begin{document}${Q}_{6}$\end{document} in Equation 11. With these quantities, we address a proposed hexatic-nematic crossover in epithelial tissue, where hexatic order dominates at small scales and nematic order prevails at larger scales (Eckert et al., 2023; Armengol-Collado et al., 2023; Armengol-Collado et al., 2024). For these three tasks, we analyze simulation data from two computational models (see Appendix 1 including additional references Hakim and Silberzan, 2017; Alert and Trepat, 2020; Moure and Gomez, 2021; Koride et al., 2018; Das et al., 2021; Killeen et al., 2022), the active vertex model (Appendix 1 -Active vertex model, including additional references Honda, 1983; Honda, 2022; Farhadifar et al., 2007; Bi et al., 2015; Tong et al., 2023) and the multiphase field model (Appendix 1 - Multiphase field model, including additional references Vey and Voigt, 2007; Witkowski et al., 2015; Praetorius and Voigt, 2018; Salvalaglio et al., 2021). Although these models differ conceptually, both have been validated in studies of cell monolayer mechanics, including solid-liquid transitions, neighbor exchange dynamics, and stress profiles (Fletcher et al., 2014; Alt et al., 2017; Li et al., 2019; Balasubramaniam et al., 2021; Wenzel and Voigt, 2021; Sknepnek et al., 2023; Melo et al., 2023). Key model parameters are the deformability and the activity strength. They are crucial for capturing the coarse-grained properties of confluent tissues (Jain et al., 2023; Jain et al., 2024). In the active vertex model, deformability is controlled by the target shape index p0\begin{document}$p_{0}$\end{document}, reflecting the balance between cell-cell adhesion and cortical tension. The multiphase field model, by contrast, encodes deformability through the capillary number Ca\begin{document}$Ca$\end{document}, which directly incorporates cortical tension. We vary activity strength (v0\begin{document}$v_{0}$\end{document}), the shape index (p0\begin{document}$p_{0}$\end{document}), and the capillary number (Ca\begin{document}$Ca$\end{document}), ensuring all parameter combinations remain in the fluid regime. Fluidity was confirmed using by mean square displacement (MSD) (Loewe et al., 2020), neighbor number variance (Wenzel and Voigt, 2021), and the self-intermediate scattering function (Bi et al., 2016).

These studies demonstrate independence of q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document}, a general trend of increasing q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{2}}$\end{document} and decreasing q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{6}}$\end{document} for higher activity and deformability, and a consistent decrease of Q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{2}}$\end{document} and Q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{6}}$\end{document} for increasing coarse-graining radius R\begin{document}$R$\end{document}. However, as q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} are not directly comparable and q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} (and, therefore, also Q2\begin{document}$Q_{2}$\end{document} and Q6\begin{document}$Q_{6}$\end{document}) are independent, the concept of a hexatic-nematic transition - typically requiring a single order parameter - may not be applicable in this context. Even if the proposed hexatic-nematic crossover (Armengol-Collado et al., 2023) is not a formal phase transition, one might expect it to be quantifiable. Yet, its characterization appears to depend strongly on the maximum attainable value of q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document}, which in turn is influenced by several parameters. To further explore this, we reanalyze the experimental data for MDCK cells from Armengol-Collado et al., 2023 using Minkowski tensors and compute q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} as defined in Equation 7 (see Appendix 1-Experimental setup for details on the analysis of this experimental data with additional references Stringer et al., 2021; van der Walt et al., 2014). Our analysis also indicates independence of q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} supporting the same interpretation as above. The statistical properties and probability distributions of these data remain consistent when full cellular boundaries from microscopy images are used. However, an increase in hexatic order (p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document}) is observed when cell shapes are approximated by polygons. This suggests that the dominant hexatic order reported at the cellular scale in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023 may stem from the geometric simplification of cell boundaries. We also compute Q2\begin{document}$Q_{2}$\end{document} and Q6\begin{document}$Q_{6}$\end{document} (Equation 11) and again observed a consistent decrease with increasing coarse-graining radius R\begin{document}$R$\end{document}, without evidence of a measurable hexatic-nematic crossover. To better understand the differences with the findings in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023, we further analyze both simulation and experimental data using the alternative shape measures γp\begin{document}$\gamma_{p}$\end{document} (Equation 8) and Γp\begin{document}$\Gamma_{p}$\end{document} (Equation 12) considered in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023. These measures reproduce the reported results.

sec.title: Independence of q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document}
sec.p: We examine the distribution of (q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document}, q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document}) values across deformability-activity parameter pairs in both computational models (Figure 7). Both models show consistent trends: In near-solid regimes (Figure 7 lower left), q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} values cluster tightly due to restricted shape fluctuations. However, even in this regime, small q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} values can correspond to either small or large q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} values, and vice versa. In more fluid-like regimes, with higher activity and higher deformability (Figure 7 upper right), q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} values become highly scattered. Each q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} value spans a broad range of q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} values, and vice versa, indicating their independence. In order to quantify this, we compute the distance correlation (Székely et al., 2007), which is a statistical measure quantifying linear and non-linear dependency in given data. Thereby, a value of 0.0 corresponds to independence, whereas a value of 1.0\begin{document}$1.0$\end{document} corresponds to a strong dependence between the datasets. As can be seen in Figure 7—figure supplement 1 the obtained distance correlation for q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} is quite low, underscoring that these quantities are independent. Furthermore, the corresponding p-values, as shown in Figure 7—figure supplement 2 are mostly larger than 0.1\begin{document}$0.1$\end{document}, indicating that the weak correlation found in Figure 7—figure supplement 1 is not significant. This leads to the conclusion that q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} measure distinct aspects of cell shape anisotropy. As a consequence, both orders, nematic and hexatic, need to be considered independently. There cannot be a single parameter which describes a crossover between both.

caption.title: Nematic (p=2\begin{document}$p=2$\end{document}) and hexatic (p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document}) orders are independent of each other.

For each cell and each timestep, we plot one point (q2,q6)\begin{document}$(q_{2},q_{6})$\end{document}. Each panel corresponds to specific model parameters; Ca\begin{document}$Ca$\end{document} and v0\begin{document}$v_{0}$\end{document} for multiphase field model, and p0\begin{document}$p_{0}$\end{document} and v0\begin{document}$v_{0}$\end{document} for the active vertex model, representing deformability and activity, respectively.

sec.p: A full investigation of potential dependencies between qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document} for arbitrary combinations of p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}’s resulting, e.g., from symmetry arguments is beyond the scope of this paper.

sec.title: Dependence of qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document} on activity and deformability
sec.p: We now explore how tissue properties such as activity and deformability influence cell shape and orientational order. We again focus on nematic (p=2\begin{document}$p=2$\end{document}) and hexatic (p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document}) orders, as shown in Figure 8—figure supplements 1 and 2. Additional results for p=3,4,5\begin{document}$p=3,4,5$\end{document} are provided in Appendix 2-Results for q3\begin{document}$q_{3}$\end{document}, q4\begin{document}$q_{4}$\end{document}, and q5\begin{document}$q_{5}$\end{document}, precisely in Appendix 2—figure 1 - Appendix 2—figure 3 (fixed activity) and Appendix 2—figure 4, Appendix 2—figure 5, Appendix 2—figure 6 (fixed deformability). In all plots, all cells and all time steps are considered. In Figure 8—figure supplement 1, we vary deformability (p0\begin{document}$p_{0}$\end{document} in the active vertex model and Ca\begin{document}$Ca$\end{document} in the multiphase field model) while keeping the activity v0\begin{document}$v_{0}$\end{document} constant. Results are presented for the active vertex model (left column) and the multiphase field model (right column). Activity increases from bottom to top rows. Both models show qualitatively similar trends in the probability distribution functions (PDFs) of q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document}. For p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document}, increasing deformability shifts the PDF of q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} to the left, indicating lower mean values. In contrast, for p=2\begin{document}$p=2$\end{document}, higher deformability leads to higher q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} values, reflected in a rightward shift of the PDF. This trend is confirmed by the mean values, shown as a function of deformability (p0\begin{document}$p_{0}$\end{document} and Ca\begin{document}$Ca$\end{document}, respectively) in the inlets. Additionally, the PDFs broaden with increasing deformability, and this effect is more pronounced at lower activity levels. A notable difference between the models is the range of qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document} values. In the multiphase field model, qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document} rarely exceeds 0.8\begin{document}$0.8$\end{document} due to the smoother, more rounded cell shapes, whereas the active vertex model often produces higher qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document} values. In Figure 8—figure supplement 2, deformability is held constant while activity v0\begin{document}$v_{0}$\end{document} is varied. Results are again shown for the active vertex model (left column) and the multiphase field model (right column), with increasing activity indicated by brighter colors. Deformability increases from bottom to top rows. The trends mirror those observed in Figure 8—figure supplement 1. Increasing activity reduces the mean value of q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} while increasing q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document}, see inlets. The effects of activity are more pronounced at lower deformabilities; at higher deformabilities, differences between parameter regimes diminish. The overall behavior of q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} is summarized in Figure 8, which shows the mean values q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{2}}$\end{document} and q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{6}}$\end{document} as functions of activity and deformability. For both models:

list-item.p: q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{2}}$\end{document} increases with higher activity or deformability
q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{6}}$\end{document} decreases with higher activity or deformability.

(a-d) active vertex model and (e-h) multiphase field model for decreasing deformability.

sec.p: This behavior is consistent with a trend towards nematic order in more dynamic regimes and towards hexatic order in more constrained, less dynamic regimes. The first is further confirmed by recent findings in analysing T1 transitions and their effect on cell shapes (Jain et al., 2025). These studies suggest that cells transiently elongate when they are undergoing T1 transitions. As the number of T1 transitions increases with activity or deformability Jain et al., 2024, this elongation contributes to the observed behavior. The second is consistent with the emergence of hexagonal arrangements in solid-like states.

Corresponding results for p=3,4,5\begin{document}$p=3,4,5$\end{document} are shown in Appendix 2—figure 7. While q3\begin{document}$q_{3}$\end{document}, q4\begin{document}$q_{4}$\end{document}, q5\begin{document}$q_{5}$\end{document} also increase with increasing activity or deformability, the dependency is not as pronounced as for q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document}.

sec.title: Coarse-grained quantities Q2\begin{document}$Q_{2}$\end{document} and Q6\begin{document}$Q_{6}$\end{document} and potential hexatic-nematic crossover
sec.p: For every parameter configuration in the active vertex model (Figure 9—figure supplement 1) and in the multiphase field model (Figure 9—figure supplement 2) we compute the coarse-grained quantities Q2\begin{document}$Q_{2}$\end{document} and Q6\begin{document}$Q_{6}$\end{document} for various coarse-graining radii R\begin{document}$R$\end{document}. One might ask the question if the observed trends for q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{2}}$\end{document} and q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{6}}$\end{document} for higher activity and deformability in Figure 8 are also present on larger scales. We, therefore, investigate the behavior of Q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{2}}$\end{document} and Q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{6}}$\end{document} upon varying activity and deformability, see Figure 9. This is exemplified for R/Rcell=8.0\begin{document}$R/R_{cell}=8.0$\end{document}. The trends seen for q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{2}}$\end{document} and q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{6}}$\end{document} - so increasing (q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{2}}$\end{document}) or decreasing (q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{6}}$\end{document}) with higher activity or deformability - are lost for Q¯2\begin{document}$\overline Q_2$\end{document} and less pronounced for Q¯6\begin{document}$\overline Q_6$\end{document}.

caption.title: Coarse-gained nematic (p=2\begin{document}$p=2$\end{document}) and hexatic (p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document}) order for R/Rcell=8\begin{document}$R/R_{cell}=8$\end{document} depend on activity and deformability of the cells.
caption.p: Mean value Qp¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{p}}$\end{document} for p=2\begin{document}$p=2$\end{document} (left) and p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document} (right) as function of deformability p0\begin{document}$p_{0}$\end{document} or Ca\begin{document}$Ca$\end{document} and activity v0\begin{document}$v_{0}$\end{document} for active vertex model (a\begin{document}$a$\end{document} and b\begin{document}$b$\end{document}) and multiphase field model (c\begin{document}$c$\end{document} and d\begin{document}$d$\end{document}).

caption.title: Q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{6}}$\end{document} versus Q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{2}}$\end{document} for different coarse-graining radii in the active vertex model.
caption.p: Qp\begin{document}$Q_{p}$\end{document} was calculated according to Equation 11, the averaging of this and the choice of Rcell\begin{document}$R_{cell}$\end{document} follow the description in Coarse-grained quantities. The maximal coarse-graining radius corresponds to half the domain width. Each panel corresponds to specific model parameters; p0\begin{document}$p_{0}$\end{document} and v0\begin{document}$v_{0}$\end{document}, representing deformability and activity. A logarithmic scaling was used for both axes. Error bars are obtained as s.e.m.

caption.title: Q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{6}}$\end{document} versus Q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{2}}$\end{document} for different coarse-graining radii in the multiphase field model.
caption.p: Qp\begin{document}$Q_{p}$\end{document} was calculated according to Equation 11, the averaging of this and the choice of Rcell\begin{document}$R_{cell}$\end{document} follow the description in Coarse-grained quantities. The maximal coarse-graining radius corresponds to half the domain width. Each panel corresponds to specific model parameters; Ca\begin{document}$Ca$\end{document} and v0\begin{document}$v_{0}$\end{document}, representing deformability and activity. A logarithmic scaling was used for both axes. Error bars are obtained as s.e.m.

sec.p: In Armengol-Collado et al., 2023 a similar approach was used to identify a hexatic-nematic crossover (see Armengol-Collado et al., 2023, Figure 3e). This cross-over is considered at the coarse-graining radius at which the two curves for Q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{2}}$\end{document} and Q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{6}}$\end{document} as a function of R\begin{document}$R$\end{document} cross. While already conceptually questioned above, we consider these investigations to compare with Armengol-Collado et al., 2023. However, regardless of the model, there is no consistent trend indicative of a potential crossover. These results question the proposed hexatic-nematic crossover reported in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023. To further explore this issue, we next test the existence of such a crossover directly on the data considered in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023.

sec.title: Analyzing experimental data for MDCK cells
sec.p: The experimental data for confluent monolayers of MDCK GII cells used in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023 are provided in two different formats, as microscopy images and as polygon data with the calculated vertex points per cell. We consider both formats and all 68 provided configurations. The polygonal data are directly used to compute q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document}. The experimental microscopy images are segmented and the extracted cell boundaries are used to compute q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document}.

We compute the PDFs of q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document}, Figure 10a for both data sets. While they are similar, if the full cellular contour from the microscopy images is considered the PDFs strongly differ if the polygonal shapes are used. The dominating hexatic (p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document}) order is, therefore, just a consequence of the approximation of the cell boundaries by polygons. This different behavior, which shows larger values for q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} for the polygonal shapes has the same origin as the difference between the regular and rounded shapes in Figure 4. Further differences result from the different accessible parameter range. While q6=1.0\begin{document}$q_{6}=1.0$\end{document} is possible for a perfect hexagon, q2=1.0\begin{document}$q_{2}=1.0$\end{document} cannot be realized, as this would correspond to a line.

caption.title: Nematic (p=2\begin{document}$p=2$\end{document}) and hexatic (p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document}) order for the cells in the experiments from Armengol-Collado et al., 2023.
caption.p: (a) Probability distribution functions (PDFs) using kde-plots, for q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} (yellow) and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} (blue), once using the polygonal approximation of the cell shape and once using the detailed cell outline obtained from the microscopy pictures. (b) q6\begin{document}$q_6$\end{document} (y-axis) versus q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} (x-axis) for all cells from the experimental data in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023, once using the polygonal approximation of the cell shape (blue) and once using the detailed cell outline obtained from the microscopy pictures (red). For each cell and each timestep, we plot one point (q2,q6)\begin{document}$(q_{2},q_{6})$\end{document}.

caption.title: Experimental image, segmented cell outline and polygonal shape.
caption.p: Cell shapes in the experiments from Armengol-Collado et al., 2023. (a) Cell shapes used for the shape quantification, (b) Detailed cell outline obtained from the microscopy image, (c) Polygonal approximation of the cell shape. Shown for frame number 1.

caption.title: Distance correlation dCor(q2,q6)\begin{document}$dCor(q_{2},q_{6})$\end{document} between q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document}.
caption.p: On the left side (a) we use the polygonal approximation of the cell shape, on the right side (b) we use the detailed cell outline obtained from the microscopy pictures. We compute one value for every frame and present the resulting distribution with a box plot. In the box plots, the orange line corresponds to the median of the data and the box ranges from the first to the third quartile of the data. The whiskers go from the lowest data point greater than (value of the first quartile) − 1.5 × (Interquartile range) to the highest data point below (value of the third quartile) + 1.5 × (Interquartile range). Outliers are shown with circles.

caption.title: P-values of the distance correlation PdCor(q2,q6)\begin{document}$P_{dCor(q_{2},q_6)}$\end{document} between q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document}.
caption.p: On the left side (a) we use the polygonal approximation of the cell shape, on the right side (b) we use the detailed cell outline obtained from the microscopy pictures. We compute one value for every frame and present the resulting distribution with a box plot. In the box plots, the orange line corresponds to the median of the data and the box ranges from the first to the third quartile of the data. The whiskers go from the lowest data point greater than (value of the first quartile) − 1.5 × (Interquartile range) to the highest data point below (value of the third quartile) + 1.5 × (Interquartile range). Outliers are shown with circles. 0.05 and 0.1 are marked with a gray dotted/gray dashed line to guide the eye.

sec.p: We also test the values for q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} for independence, see Figure 10b and in the corresponding statistical measures, Figure 10—figure supplements 2 and 3. The indicated independence in the scatter plots Figure 10b is confirmed by the distance correlation and the p-values, as in Figure 7, Figure 7—figure supplement 1 and Figure 7—figure supplement 2. This holds for the polygonal shapes as well as for the more detailed shapes from the microscopy images.

As a consequence, the same arguments as discussed above also hold for the experimental data and thus caution against interpretation of q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} or their coarse-grained quantities Q2\begin{document}$Q_{2}$\end{document} and Q6\begin{document}$Q_{6}$\end{document} as interdependent order parameters. However, in order to compare with Armengol-Collado et al., 2023 we next compute the averaged coarse-grained quantities Q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{2}}$\end{document} and Q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{6}}$\end{document} for various coarse-graining radii R\begin{document}$R$\end{document}. In Figure 11 these curves are shown for the polygonal shapes (a) and the microscopy images (b). As in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023, we carried out the coarse-graining until the coarse-graining radius corresponds to half of the domain width. In both plots, the curves for Q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{2}}$\end{document} are almost identical, reflecting the similar PDFs in Figure 10a. For Q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{6}}$\end{document} the slope is similar but the curves are shifted. A potential crossover, therefore, also depends on the approximation of the cells. In any case, for the considered data, no consistent hexatic-nematic crossover can be observed.

caption.title: Q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{6}}$\end{document} versus Q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{2}}$\end{document} for different coarse-graining radii for the experimental data from Armengol-Collado et al., 2023.
caption.p: On the left side (a) we use the polygonal approximation of the cell shape, on the right side (b) we use the detailed cell outline obtained from the microscopy pictures. Qp\begin{document}$Q_{p}$\end{document} was calculated according to Equation 11, the averaging of this and the choice of Rcell\begin{document}$R_{cell}$\end{document} follow the description in Coarse-grained quantities. The maximal coarse-graining radius corresponds to half the domain width. A logarithmic scaling was used for both axes. Error bars are obtained as s.e.m.

sec.p: In order to resolve the discrepancy of these results with Armengol-Collado et al., 2023 we next examine the analysis using the alternative shape measures γp\begin{document}$\gamma_{p}$\end{document} in Equation 8, which have been considered in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023 but are shown to be not stable.

sec.title: Sensitivity of the results on the considered shape descriptor
sec.p: We now demonstrate that the alternative shape descriptors γp\begin{document}$\gamma_{p}$\end{document} in Equation 8, which have been used in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023, can lead to qualitatively different and thus misleading results. The corresponding figures to Figures 1 and 2 and Figure 4 are shown in Appendix 2 -Results using polygonal shape analysis, precisely in Appendix 2—figure 9, Appendix 2—figure 10 and Appendix 2—figure 8, respectively. For the experimental data in Figures 1 and 2 we use the Voronoi interface method (Saye and Sethian, 2011; Saye and Sethian, 2012) to calculate the vertices of a polygon approximating the cell shape. The comparison of these figures already indicates differences between the two methods. Such differences can be seen in the approximated cell shapes, the PDFs and more quantitatively also by comparing |γp|¯\begin{document}$\overline{|\gamma_{p}|}$\end{document} in Appendix 2—figure 10a with qp¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{p}}$\end{document} in Figure 2a , which, e.g., for p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document} almost double.

For a more detailed comparison of |γp|\begin{document}$|\gamma_{p}|$\end{document} and qp\begin{document}$q_{p}$\end{document} we investigate the data from the active vertex model and the polygonal approximation of the cells in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023. We restrict ourselves to this data, as for multiphase field data, the usage of γp\begin{document}$\gamma_{p}$\end{document} first requires the approximation of a cell by a polygon and we have already seen that this approximation strongly influences the results.

We focus on Figure 8 and the corresponding results in Figure 12. Instead of the monotonic trend for activity and deformability, which was found for q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{q_{6}}$\end{document}, |γ6|¯\begin{document}$\overline{|\gamma_{6}|}$\end{document} exhibits non-monotonic trends, peaking at intermediate values of activity or deformability. For completeness, we also provide the corresponding figures to Figures 7 and 9 in Appendix 2—figures 11 and 12, respectively.

caption.title: Mean value |γp|¯\begin{document}$\overline{|\gamma_{p}|}$\end{document} as function of deformability p0\begin{document}$p_{0}$\end{document} and activity v0\begin{document}$v_{0}$\end{document} for active vertex model.
caption.p: (a) nematic order (p=2\begin{document}$p=2$\end{document}), (b) hexatic order (p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document}).

sec.p: For the polygonal data of the MDCK cells considered in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023, we compare the coarse-grained quantities Q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{2}}$\end{document} and Q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{6}}$\end{document}, already considered in Figure 11a, with |Γ2|¯\begin{document}$\overline{|\Gamma_{2}|}$\end{document} and |Γ6|¯\begin{document}$\overline{|\Gamma_{6}|}$\end{document} computed from γ2\begin{document}$\gamma_{2}$\end{document} and γ6\begin{document}$\gamma_{6}$\end{document} using Equation 12, see Figure 13. For completeness, we also provide the corresponding figure to Figure 10 in Appendix 2—figure 13. Besides minor differences regarding the calculation of Rcell\begin{document}$R_{cell}$\end{document} Figure 13 corresponds to Armengol-Collado et al., 2023, Figure 3e. Comparing Figure 11a and Figure 13 one might come to the conclusion that there is no hexatic-nematic crossover using Q2¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{2}}$\end{document} and Q6¯\begin{document}$\overline{Q_{6}}$\end{document}, but there is a hexatic-nematic crossover using |Γ2|¯\begin{document}$\overline{|\Gamma_{2}|}$\end{document} and |Γ6|¯\begin{document}$\overline{|\Gamma_{6}|}$\end{document}. As the only difference between these two evaluations is the considered shape characterization, this analysis adds another argument that the proposed crossover is not a robust physical feature of the system.

caption.title: |Γ6|¯\begin{document}$\overline{|\Gamma_{6}|}$\end{document} versus |Γ2|¯\begin{document}$\overline{|\Gamma_{2}|}$\end{document} for different coarse-graining radii for the experimental data from Armengol-Collado et al., 2023.
caption.p: We use only the polygonal approximation of the cell shape as γp\begin{document}$\gamma_{p}$\end{document} can only work with polygons. Qp\begin{document}$Q_{p}$\end{document} was calculated according to Equation 12, the averaging of this and the choice of Rcell\begin{document}$R_{cell}$\end{document} follow the description in Coarse-grained quantities. The maximal coarse-graining radius corresponds to half the domain width. A logarithmic scaling was used for both axes. Error bars are obtained as s.e.m.

sec.p: These results also demonstrate that not only the approximation of the cell boundaries by polygonal shapes heavily influences the characterization of p-atic order but also the considered method to classify the shape might lead to qualitative different results. This confirms the argumentation in Methods that Minkowski tensors should be preferred because of their stability properties.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we introduced Minkowski tensors as a robust and versatile tool for quantifying p-atic order in multicellular systems, particularly in scenarios involving rounded or irregular cell shapes. By applying this framework to extensive datasets from two distinct computational models—the active vertex model and the multiphase field model—we identified universal trends: increasing activity and deformability of the cells enhance nematic order (p=2\begin{document}$p=2$\end{document}) while diminishing hexatic order (p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document}). The consistency of these findings across two models, despite their inherent differences, underscores the generality of our results.

While various shape characterization methods, such as the bond order parameter (Loewe et al., 2020; Monfared et al., 2023) and the shape function γp\begin{document}$\gamma_{p}$\end{document} (Armengol-Collado et al., 2023), have been explored in the literature, we demonstrated that the choice of shape descriptor significantly impacts the conclusions drawn. Such divergences, together with limited mathematical foundations, highlight the limitations of these alternative shape measures in capturing consistent patterns and emphasize the need for stable, reliable shape measures like the Minkowski tensors. As the stability of Minkowski tensors - in contrast to the bond order parameter or the shape function γp\begin{document}$\gamma_{p}$\end{document} - can be mathematically justified Minkowski tensors should be the preferred shape descriptor. This finding is not merely a technical nuance, it leads to qualitative differences. Analyzing experimental data for MDCK cells, e.g., has demonstrated that a strong hexatic order on the cellular scale has no physical origin but is a consequence of the approximation of the cell boundaries by polygonal shapes, which is a requirement to use the shape function γ6\begin{document}$\gamma_{6}$\end{document}. Considering the full cellular boundaries and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document}, which is derived from the Minkowski tensors, leads to a different picture, with weaker hexatic order. A critical question in the literature has been whether shape measures for different p-atic orders can be directly compared. While some studies have suggested relationships between γ2\begin{document}$\gamma_{2}$\end{document} and γ6\begin{document}$\gamma_{6}$\end{document} (Armengol-Collado et al., 2023), our results refute this notion. We demonstrated that measures like q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} are independent and capture fundamentally distinct aspects of cell shape and alignment. Comparing them directly is mathematically but also physically and biologically misleading. We further tested the hypothesis of a hexatic-nematic crossover at larger length scales by coarse-graining q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document}. To discuss such a crossover requires direct comparison of q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document} and q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document} or their coarse-grain quantities Q2\begin{document}$Q_{2}$\end{document} and Q6\begin{document}$Q_{6}$\end{document}, which is conceptually questionable. However, the results showed no consistent trends indicative of a crossover, regardless of the considered model or the experimental data. This leads to the conclusion that the proposed hexatic-nematic crossover in Armengol-Collado et al., 2023 is not a physical phenomena but specific to the considered method.

Our findings suggest that p-atic orders should be studied independently, also across length scales, as they describe complementary aspects of cellular organization. The coexistence of distinct orientational orders emphasized in different studies—such as nematic (p=2\begin{document}$p=2$\end{document}) (Duclos et al., 2017; Saw et al., 2017; Kawaguchi et al., 2017), tetratic (p=4\begin{document}$p=4$\end{document}) (Cislo et al., 2023), and hexatic (p=6\begin{document}$p=6$\end{document}) (Li and Ciamarra, 2018)—is not contradictory but highlights the rich, multifaceted nature of cellular organization. Rather than searching for a single dominant order, future research should focus on the interplay of different p-atic orders and their associated defects. This suggests to not only consider p-atic liquid crystal theories (Giomi et al., 2022b) for one specific p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}, but combinations of these models for various p\begin{document}$p$\end{document}’s. Understanding how these orders interact may reveal how they collectively regulate morphogenetic processes.

Connecting p-atic orders to biological function remains a critical avenue for exploration. While the mathematical independence of q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document}, q6\begin{document}$q_{6}$\end{document}, and other shape measures precludes the identification of a universal dominant order, biological systems may exhibit context-dependent preferences. For example, a specific p-atic order might correlate with or drive a key morphogenetic event. Investigating these connections could yield insights into how tissues achieve functional organization and adapt to environmental cues. As such, while it is difficult to speak of dominating orders from a mathematical point of view, there could be a dominating order from a biological point of view, meaning the p-atic order connected to the governing biological process.
